title: About Sansa and Arya
body:
I need to make a post because I somehow fell into the crazy section of the Game of Thrones fandom that seems to still think Sansa is evil and also that Arya is going to kill her and replace her with Daenerys as a new sister? And I know that these theories are stupid and I really don’t have to acknowledge them, but I’m angry so I’m gonna.

Disclaimer: The Stark sisters are both in my top five favorite characters on Game of Thrones. So before ANYONE comes at me with that ‘your biased against one of them’ shit, back right the fuck away. Some of you have this weird conception that ‘Sansa stans all hate Arya’. And you’re…wrong. In the beginning, Arya was my favorite character and I didn’t like Sansa one bit. But that was because I had a lot of internalized misogyny going on that told me that the only strong female characters are ones that fight and kill things and are ‘not like other girls’. I’ve gotten over that now, so now I love them both to the moon and back and you can all fight me.

So. Let’s revisit the Stark sister fight, shall we?

Season seven. The sisters fight. And the writing…was bad. It was clearly all engineered to give us a surprise twist ending in which Sansa and Arya fooled Littlefinger. Everyone knew it right from the beginning. It was just trying to give us some pointless drama. Now at it’s LEAST annoying, this arc was just a poorly written fake out in which the Stark sisters were secretly playing Littlefinger the whole time. With that reading, it isn’t well done, but at least it doesn’t involve a gross mischaracterization of the Stark sisters.

However, according to some reports of deleted scenes, old scripts, etc. it’s possible that Sansa and Arya WERE both fooled and it was only Bran that kept them from having a true falling out. Which is dumb. it’s dumb as hell. Sansa knows not to trust Littlefinger and ARYA just spent a bunch of time learning from a super secret assassin club. She would see bull shit written all over this.

Also there is just so much that doesn’t make sense in their conversations. Arya saw Sansa absolutely sobbing and screaming on the day her father was killed and commented on her dress? She says she always wanted to wear pretty dresses? Arya is mad at Sansa for trying to blend in with the enemy when she played cup bearer to TYWIN LANNISTER and had the equivalent of an INSTA KILL which she didn’t use on him? Arya couldn’t have figured out that Sansa was probably forced to write that letter? Please. It’s SO much bullshit.

Sansa is trying to keep peace in the north and chooses to gently shut down the slightly treasonous comment from a northern lord. It was really just an expression of doubt. She knows that hard times are coming and she can’t just punish their few allies. She is in the right in this. And sure, Arya is in the right to perhaps criticize her or even raise a complaint but she would never jump to the fucking death threats. The conversation they have right after is fine! Just a little argument and differing opinions.

BUT EVEN IF YOU THINK it is ALL legitimate. Even if you think the Stark sisters really were in conflict and even if you were on Arya’s side in the situation. That does not explain why some of you think that Arya and Sansa are going to be in conflict season 8. Like did you SKIP their last fucking scene? Did you just fucking SKIP IT?

Arya asks Sansa if she is okay! And gives her credit for Littlefinger’s death! They talk honestly about their feelings! Arya admits she wouldn’t have survived what Sansa survived and Sansa calls her the STRONGEST PERSON SHE KNOWS. Like wow, yeah, what an evil bitch Sansa is. Calling Arya the strongest person she knows. Truly. Cersei 2.0.

They share a little joke about their old sisterly animosity (sisters fight sometimes, my dudes. They tease each other. It’s supposed to be cute). And then they remember their father’s words “the lone wolf dies but the pack survives”.

Ned Stark was always preaching about family and he is the one who first told Arya that she needed to make up with her sister. He was the one who told her that they have to protect each other. You think Arya would dishonor her father’s memory by KILLING her own SISTER? Are you DRUNK?

So when we leave off Sansa and Arya, they are sharing their feelings, they remember their father, they validate each other’s struggle and they are even standing in the same place as Jon and Sansa after they took back Winterfell in season 6. This is a united front! They are going into season 8 compeltely united. That was the whole purpose of their arc! To bind them together as family again.

I just…Sansa is not the villain you want her to be guys. She just isn’t. Maise, on the other hand, admitted she played Arya as a villain in that arc which…yeah she did. Her acting was very villainous (which I’m fine with if it was all an act). But there is no way you can watch that last scene and think that there is any hint of the Stark sisters having a falling out. It just takes BASIC film comprehension.

The Stark sisters love each other and they have each other’s backs. Arya is Sansa’s blade. They are a pack. Full stop.

summary:
More from Vanity Fair, 
The GoT scripts have been archived by HBO in the Writers Guild of America Library in LA.
 
The last...
caption:
More from Vanity Fair, The GoT scripts have been archived by HBO in the Writers Guild of America Library in LA.


The last script @GRRMspeaking wrote for the show included this scene:
“Martin has Roose Bolton tell his bastard son: “We have a much better match in mind for you. A match to help House Bolton hold the north. Arya Stark.” - George RR Martin

More book canon on the show in GRRM’s script!😮 D&D’s fanfiction needs must have been George’s #1 main reason to stop writing show scripts.
In the scripts George RR Martin wrote, he mentioned wanting GoT to go on for 12 or 13 seasons. And with more direwolf scenes!
ohmydays.
https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2018/12/game-of-thrones-george-rr-martin-last-script-the-lion-and-the-rose

title: Winterfell’s Daughter. On Sansa Stark (part 11)
body:
I’ve previously written a series of posts that analyse Sansa Stark’s narrative arc in Game of Thrones - during season 1 (Part 1, Part 2, Part 3, Part 4, Part 5, Part 6) and during season 2 (Part 7, Part 8, Part 9, Part 10). Season 2 was rather hard to watch for any fan of Sansa Stark because of the unremitting physical, sexual and emotional abuse she’s subjected to in that season. Thankfully, season 3 dials back on the abuse and in this context, it is worth noting that Sansa is repeatedly confronted with people who, with varying degrees of honesty, either promise help her escape her abusive situation or protect her from the abuse. If Sansa’s season 2 arc was about enduring abuse, then her season 3 arc is dealing with hope of an escape - a hope held out by different political players of varying trustworthiness.

Season 3 is the season where Petyr Baelish enters Sansa’s narrative in a serious and important way. He has previously interacted with her very briefly in season 1 and season 2 - but until now she hasn’t been the focus of his intrigues. From season 3 to season 7, Sansa Stark is one of the most important linchpins of Baelish’s political intrigues. His actions shapes her narrative to a very large extent. 

AN OFFER OF ESCAPE

In her very first scene of season 3 we find Sansa at a pier in the King’s Landing harbour with Shae. Sansa is inventing stories for the various ships they see but Shae doesn’t really understand the purpose of this game when Sansa invites her to join in – why make up stories about these ships when the truth is different? To which Sansa replies:

What I find particularly interesting about this particular exchange is that it highlights that Sansa hasn’t lost her love of storytelling. However, her perception of stories (and songs) have changed. Whereas the naïve and idealistic Sansa of season 1 thought that stories and songs contained the truth, the more disillusioned Sansa of season 3 sees storytelling as an escape from a reality that is either boring or terrible. That is very understandable since Sansa’s life has been rather terrible since her father was killed.

Petyr Baelish approaches Sansa and Shae. He wants to speak with Sansa alone and when they are (somewhat) alone he reveals something important to her.

Baelish: I saw your mother not long ago. She’s very eager to see you. And your sister.

Sansa (gasps): Arya’s alive? … You said you would take me home.

Baelish: You said King’s Landing was your home.

This last exchange is a call back to a conversation they had in the last episode of season 2, after Joffrey had set Sansa aside as his betrothed. At that time Sansa refused Baelish’s offer, probably because she didn’t trust him. Now, however, Baelish has found the thing that Sansa wants more than her home: her family! When he first extended his offer last season, he didn’t mention that he had met with Catelyn Stark, probably because he thought that the idea of home was enough to get Sansa to agree to his proposal. She didn’t. Now, however, he skillfully dangles the prospect of reuniting with her family – and that is a temptation that Sansa cannot resist. That he literally makes her beg for him to take her home must be very gratifying for Baelish, especially since she initially refused him.

Baelish: You are the property of the Crown. Stealing you would be treason. If you were to tell just one person…

Sansa: I won’t tell anyone.

Baelish: How do I know?

Sansa throws his own words from season 2 back in his face. Now she sounds desperate.

Sansa: Because I’m a terrible liar. You said so yourself. … Please, Lord Baelish. Tell me what to do. Tell me when.

This is where they once again enter the dynamic that season 1 established between them: Baelish is making Sansa keep secrets through the implied threat of bodily harm (though always from persons other than him). This is a dynamic that we’ll see play out again and again as Baelish draws Sansa into more and more dangerous secrets and it offers him a way to control her and make her dependent on him. He enjoys the power that Sansa’s desperation gives him and now he gives a little performance of hesitance to make her even more desperate.

Baelish: I’m waiting for word on an assignment that will take me far away from the capital. When I set sail, I might be able to take you with me. But you’ll need to be ready to leave on a moment’s notice.

This reads a bit like him punishing her for refusing his initial offer – and we know how Baelish likes to punish those who refuse to give him what he wants.

CAPTIVE PRINCESS

The conversation between Sansa and Baelish is followed by a scene between Sansa’s maid Shae and the prostitute Ros who works in Baelish’s brothel but who’s also spying on behalf of Lord Varys. This part of the sequence begins with a shot of Sansa and Baelish with with their backs to the camera. Shae is in frame, observing them. Ros approaches Shae and says that Sansa is an important person. 

Ros grew up near Winterfell and she tells Shae of how Lord Stark had the bells rung from sunrise to sunset the day that Sansa was born. 

This is a particularly interesting detail because it invokes an age-old tradition of announcing royal births with both a series of gun salutes as well as specially composed bell peals. It is a tradition that is still in use in the United Kingdom where the birth of Prince George in 2013 was celebrated with a special bell peal that lasted 3 hours! (x)  

Thus, Sansa’s birth was celebrated as if she were a royal princess, which is a curious detail since the Starks have not been Kings in the North for several centuries.

This is a detail that was invented for the show - and I cannot help but wonder if this apparently innocuous detail might be a piece of cleverly hidden foreshadowing of Sansa’s eventual fate. She may end up becoming Queen, which isn’t a far-fetched idea since queenship is a theme the runs through her narrative arc in the books - even after she’s no longer betrothed to Joffrey. Sansa is, in many respects, a foil to Cersei and it is through Cersei that she learns how NOT to be a Queen! Neither should we forget that in the moment of crisis during the Battle of Blackwater, it was Sansa who stepped up and performed Cersei’s role when the latter abandoned her duties.

Ros is leading the conversation with Shae, perhaps fishing for information now that she works for Varys, but when Baelish turns and walks towards them, Ros issues a quick warning:

Ros (to Shae): Watch out for her.

Shae: I always do.

Ros: Watch out for her with him.

It is interesting that Ros gives this particular warning – what is her reason for trying to look out for Sansa? Is it simply because she grew up near Winterfell or is there something more in play? We never get an answer to this question but I do find it interesting that this low-born prostitute cares enough to warn Sansa’s maid about Baelish’s nefarious interest in the aristocratic girl.

The scene ends with a shot of Sansa with her back to the camera, standing very still and looking out at the sea. We cannot read her emotions because we don’t have access to her face. Thus, we have to imagine what she thinks and feels. 

In this respect, the image composition is interesting because a figure, seen from behind, looking out at something is often used as a device for a heightened submersion into the motif on the part of the spectator:

“…the presence of static figures, seen from behind […] permits the spectator a maximum of empathy, for he can easily take his place beside or within these faceless beings…” (Robert Rosenblum, Modern Painting and the Northern Romantic Tradition)

Furthermore, in the history of art, images of a figure looking out at the sea or a harbor with their back turned to the spectator has often been used to convey longing, fx for travel or adventure. Thus, it is not far-fetched to interpret this image of Sansa as her being submerged in a moment of longing for home, now that her hopes have been raised.

After this final shot of Sansa, looking out at the sea with longing, the screen  transitions to a scene on the open sea where Daenerys travels towards Astapor while her dragons fly free around the ship. In television and cinema, editing is an extremely important narrative device and it can carry a lot of meaning. Whilst Sansa’s and Daenerys’ narrative arcs are completely separate from each other, this transition from a woman longing for freedom to a woman who has embarked on a journey to take charge of her life and her ambitions forms a very poignant juxtaposition.

A WORRIED FRIEND

Sansa may have promised Baelish not to tell anyone about his plan to spirit her away from King’s Landing, but in the very next episode a scene between her and Shae in her chambers reveals that Sansa has confided in her maid. It isn’t stated directly but it can be deduced from the dialogue. What I find interesting is that Sansa promised Baelish to not tell as soul but here we have her discussing his offer with her maid and friend – and it just shows how much she trusts Shae.

We enter the scene mid-conversation, with Sansa telling Shae that Baelish said he didn’t want anything from her and that he’s only offering to help her because he loved her mother. Shae is, however, not quite convinced of the purity of Baelish’s intentions, courtesy of Ros’ warning.

Shae is justifiably skeptical – she rightly suspects Baelish of having an agenda with Sansa, though she thinks that Baelish’s interest in Sansa is primarily sexual (understandable considering her background). However, later episodes of this season make it clear that Baelish’s interest in Sansa is primarily political though he transfers his obsession with Catelyn Stark onto her daughter in season 4. Sansa, on the other hand, finds Shae’s insinuation rather ridiculous.

Sansa is right, he’s not in love with her. He wants to exploit her political status as Robb Stark’s heir. With the supposed deaths of Bran and Rickon Stark, Sansa has become the Robb’s heir in the eyes of Westeros - she is, politically speaking, the Key to the North if Robb dies and it is this political status that shapes her narrative arc in season 3.

Shae: Love is not the thing he wants.

I love Sansa’s expression here! Petyr Baelish is about the same age as her mother and to the rather innocent Sansa it is inconceivable that a man of that age could have a sexual interest in a 14 year-old girl. Shae knows better.

Shae: They never see it that way. He didn’t ask you to do something for him? Spy on someone or…

Sansa: No.

Sansa (smiling): Why? What would you do?

Shae: I will make him stop.

Sansa gives a soft little smile here, which is wonderful to see. Shae is so fiercely maternal in this scene – it is clear that she has taken Ros’ warning to heart. As a fan of Sansa’s character it is rather nice to see that at least one person in King’s Landing is concerned about her welfare. I’ve previously written about the maternal subtext that informs the way the show has written the relationship between Sansa and Shae. The genuine friendship between these two women is one of the few instances where the show improves upon the books - because female friendship is a HUGE blind-spot in GRRM’s writing, which lacks any kind of positive relationships between women. I love that, in the show, Shae genuinely loves Sansa and that she is fiercely protective of her, which is confirmed when she in episode 10 angrily tells Varys:

Shae: I love that girl. I would kill for her.

In the books, Sansa has NO true allies in King’s Landing.  But having a meaningful friendship with Shae doesn’t really alter Sansa’s general isolation at the royal court because Shae is powerless – though she actually tries to take steps to protect Sansa from Baelish by taking her worries to her lover Tyrion.

IT IS WORTH NOTING THAT SHAE DOES NOT REVEAL BAELISH’S OFFER TO SPIRIT SANSA AWAY FROM THE CITY AND THE LANNISTERS! Though Shae genuinely loves Tyrion, she doesn’t trust him with this secret - and I cannot stress enough how important this detail is! Throughout this season, Shae repeatedly protects Sansa’s secrets despite the fact that these secrets are against the interests of her lover’s family. Not only does she keep Sansa’s secrets, she also tries to enlist Tyrion’s help in protecting her.

Shae: We have to protect her.

Tyrion: We can’t. Now that the Lannisters have discarded her, Sansa will have many suitors. A great beauty with a very old name.

This is where the conversation about protecting Sansa is derailed by Shae’s jealousy. She gets angry and jealous by Tyrion finding Sansa beautiful. However, Shae NEVER blames Sansa for Tyrion finding her beautiful, as so many stories are wont to do. Shae blames Tyrion for finding Sansa attractive.

Shae: You pervert. You want her? This child?

Shae’s jealousy is rooted in her insecurity, knowing that she can never marry Tyrion. But she also seems angry and disappointed that Tyrion may be attracted to a girl as young as Sansa.

This fight between Shae and Tyrion also serves to highlight the theme that comes to dominate Sansa’s narrative arc in the third season of Game of Thrones: Marriage. With the supposed deaths of Bran and Rickon Stark, Sansa is now effectively Robb Stark’s heir - and that makes her an attractive prospect for a political marriage since she is, as Robb’s heir, the Key to the North.


To be continued…

body_abstract:
I’ve previously written a series of posts that analyse Sansa Stark’s narrative arc in Game of Thrones - during season 1 (Part 1, Part 2, Part 3, Part 4, Part 5, Part 6) and during season 2 (Part 7, Part 8, Part 9, Part 10). Season 2 was rather hard to watch for any fan of Sansa Stark because of the unremitting physical, sexual and emotional abuse she’s subjected to in that season. Thankfully, season 3 dials back on the abuse and in this context, it is worth noting that Sansa is repeatedly confronted with people who, with varying degrees of honesty, either promise help her escape her abusive situation or protect her from the abuse. If Sansa’s season 2 arc was about enduring abuse, then her season 3 arc is dealing with hope of an escape - a hope held out by different political players of varying trustworthiness.

Season 3 is the season where Petyr Baelish enters Sansa’s narrative in a serious and important way. He has previously interacted with her very briefly in season 1 and season 2 - but until now she hasn’t been the focus of his intrigues. From season 3 to season 7, Sansa Stark is one of the most important linchpins of Baelish’s political intrigues. His actions shapes her narrative to a very large extent.

Sansa (gasps): Arya’s alive? … You said you would take me home.

Sansa, on the other hand, finds Shae’s insinuation rather ridiculous.

Sansa is right, he’s not in love with her. He wants to exploit her political status as Robb Stark’s heir. With the supposed deaths of Bran and Rickon Stark, Sansa has become the Robb’s heir in the eyes of Westeros - she is, politically speaking, the Key to the North if Robb dies and it is this political status that shapes her narrative arc in season 3.

Shae: Love is not the thing he wants.

I love Sansa’s expression here! Petyr Baelish is about the same age as her mother and to the rather innocent Sansa it is inconceivable that a man of that age could have a sexual interest in a 14 year-old girl. Shae knows better.

Shae: They never see it that way. He didn’t ask you to do something for him? Spy on someone or…

Sansa: No.

Sansa (smiling): Why? What would you do?

Shae: I will make him stop.

Sansa gives a soft little smile here, which is wonderful to see. Shae is so fiercely maternal in this scene – it is clear that she has taken Ros’ warning to heart. As a fan of Sansa’s character it is rather nice to see that at least one person in King’s Landing is concerned about her welfare. I’ve previously written about the maternal subtext that informs the way the show has written the relationship between Sansa and Shae. The genuine friendship between these two women is one of the few instances where the show improves upon the books - because female friendship is a HUGE blind-spot in GRRM’s writing, which lacks any kind of positive relationships between women. I love that, in the show, Shae genuinely loves Sansa and that she is fiercely protective of her, which is confirmed when she in episode 10 angrily tells Varys:

Shae: I love that girl. I would kill for her.

In the books, Sansa has NO true allies in King’s Landing.  But having a meaningful friendship with Shae doesn’t really alter Sansa’s general isolation at the royal court because Shae is powerless – though she actually tries to take steps to protect Sansa from Baelish by taking her worries to her lover Tyrion.

IT IS WORTH NOTING THAT SHAE DOES NOT REVEAL BAELISH’S OFFER TO SPIRIT SANSA AWAY FROM THE CITY AND THE LANNISTERS! Though Shae genuinely loves Tyrion, she doesn’t trust him with this secret - and I cannot stress enough how important this detail is! Throughout this season, Shae repeatedly protects Sansa’s secrets despite the fact that these secrets are against the interests of her lover’s family. Not only does she keep Sansa’s secrets, she also tries to enlist Tyrion’s help in protecting her.

Shae: We have to protect her.

Tyrion: We can’t. Now that the Lannisters have discarded her, Sansa will have many suitors. A great beauty with a very old name.

This is where the conversation about protecting Sansa is derailed by Shae’s jealousy. She gets angry and jealous by Tyrion finding Sansa beautiful. However, Shae NEVER blames Sansa for Tyrion finding her beautiful, as so many stories are wont to do. Shae blames Tyrion for finding Sansa attractive.

Shae: You pervert. You want her? This child?

Shae’s jealousy is rooted in her insecurity, knowing that she can never marry Tyrion. But she also seems angry and disappointed that Tyrion may be attracted to a girl as young as Sansa.

This fight between Shae and Tyrion also serves to highlight the theme that comes to dominate Sansa’s narrative arc in the third season of Game of Thrones: Marriage. With the supposed deaths of Bran and Rickon Stark, Sansa is now effectively Robb Stark’s heir - and that makes her an attractive prospect for a political marriage since she is, as Robb’s heir, the Key to the North.


To be continued…

trail.content:
I’ve previously written a series of posts that analyse Sansa Stark’s narrative arc in Game of Thrones - during season 1 (Part 1, Part 2, Part 3, Part 4, Part 5, Part 6) and during season 2 (Part 7, Part 8, Part 9, Part 10). Season 2 was rather hard to watch for any fan of Sansa Stark because of the unremitting physical, sexual and emotional abuse she’s subjected to in that season. Thankfully, season 3 dials back on the abuse and in this context, it is worth noting that Sansa is repeatedly confronted with people who, with varying degrees of honesty, either promise help her escape her abusive situation or protect her from the abuse. If Sansa’s season 2 arc was about enduring abuse, then her season 3 arc is dealing with hope of an escape - a hope held out by different political players of varying trustworthiness.

Season 3 is the season where Petyr Baelish enters Sansa’s narrative in a serious and important way. He has previously interacted with her very briefly in season 1 and season 2 - but until now she hasn’t been the focus of his intrigues. From season 3 to season 7, Sansa Stark is one of the most important linchpins of Baelish’s political intrigues. His actions shapes her narrative to a very large extent. 

AN OFFER OF ESCAPE

In her very first scene of season 3 we find Sansa at a pier in the King’s Landing harbour with Shae. Sansa is inventing stories for the various ships they see but Shae doesn’t really understand the purpose of this game when Sansa invites her to join in – why make up stories about these ships when the truth is different? To which Sansa replies:

What I find particularly interesting about this particular exchange is that it highlights that Sansa hasn’t lost her love of storytelling. However, her perception of stories (and songs) have changed. Whereas the naïve and idealistic Sansa of season 1 thought that stories and songs contained the truth, the more disillusioned Sansa of season 3 sees storytelling as an escape from a reality that is either boring or terrible. That is very understandable since Sansa’s life has been rather terrible since her father was killed.

Petyr Baelish approaches Sansa and Shae. He wants to speak with Sansa alone and when they are (somewhat) alone he reveals something important to her.

Baelish: I saw your mother not long ago. She’s very eager to see you. And your sister.

Sansa (gasps): Arya’s alive? … You said you would take me home.

Baelish: You said King’s Landing was your home.

This last exchange is a call back to a conversation they had in the last episode of season 2, after Joffrey had set Sansa aside as his betrothed. At that time Sansa refused Baelish’s offer, probably because she didn’t trust him. Now, however, Baelish has found the thing that Sansa wants more than her home: her family! When he first extended his offer last season, he didn’t mention that he had met with Catelyn Stark, probably because he thought that the idea of home was enough to get Sansa to agree to his proposal. She didn’t. Now, however, he skillfully dangles the prospect of reuniting with her family – and that is a temptation that Sansa cannot resist. That he literally makes her beg for him to take her home must be very gratifying for Baelish, especially since she initially refused him.

Baelish: You are the property of the Crown. Stealing you would be treason. If you were to tell just one person…

Sansa: I won’t tell anyone.

Baelish: How do I know?

Sansa throws his own words from season 2 back in his face. Now she sounds desperate.

Sansa: Because I’m a terrible liar. You said so yourself. … Please, Lord Baelish. Tell me what to do. Tell me when.

This is where they once again enter the dynamic that season 1 established between them: Baelish is making Sansa keep secrets through the implied threat of bodily harm (though always from persons other than him). This is a dynamic that we’ll see play out again and again as Baelish draws Sansa into more and more dangerous secrets and it offers him a way to control her and make her dependent on him. He enjoys the power that Sansa’s desperation gives him and now he gives a little performance of hesitance to make her even more desperate.

Baelish: I’m waiting for word on an assignment that will take me far away from the capital. When I set sail, I might be able to take you with me. But you’ll need to be ready to leave on a moment’s notice.

This reads a bit like him punishing her for refusing his initial offer – and we know how Baelish likes to punish those who refuse to give him what he wants.

CAPTIVE PRINCESS

The conversation between Sansa and Baelish is followed by a scene between Sansa’s maid Shae and the prostitute Ros who works in Baelish’s brothel but who’s also spying on behalf of Lord Varys. This part of the sequence begins with a shot of Sansa and Baelish with with their backs to the camera. Shae is in frame, observing them. Ros approaches Shae and says that Sansa is an important person. 

Ros grew up near Winterfell and she tells Shae of how Lord Stark had the bells rung from sunrise to sunset the day that Sansa was born. 

This is a particularly interesting detail because it invokes an age-old tradition of announcing royal births with both a series of gun salutes as well as specially composed bell peals. It is a tradition that is still in use in the United Kingdom where the birth of Prince George in 2013 was celebrated with a special bell peal that lasted 3 hours! (x)  

Thus, Sansa’s birth was celebrated as if she were a royal princess, which is a curious detail since the Starks have not been Kings in the North for several centuries.

This is a detail that was invented for the show - and I cannot help but wonder if this apparently innocuous detail might be a piece of cleverly hidden foreshadowing of Sansa’s eventual fate. She may end up becoming Queen, which isn’t a far-fetched idea since queenship is a theme the runs through her narrative arc in the books - even after she’s no longer betrothed to Joffrey. Sansa is, in many respects, a foil to Cersei and it is through Cersei that she learns how NOT to be a Queen! Neither should we forget that in the moment of crisis during the Battle of Blackwater, it was Sansa who stepped up and performed Cersei’s role when the latter abandoned her duties.

Ros is leading the conversation with Shae, perhaps fishing for information now that she works for Varys, but when Baelish turns and walks towards them, Ros issues a quick warning:

Ros (to Shae): Watch out for her.

Shae: I always do.

Ros: Watch out for her with him.

It is interesting that Ros gives this particular warning – what is her reason for trying to look out for Sansa? Is it simply because she grew up near Winterfell or is there something more in play? We never get an answer to this question but I do find it interesting that this low-born prostitute cares enough to warn Sansa’s maid about Baelish’s nefarious interest in the aristocratic girl.

The scene ends with a shot of Sansa with her back to the camera, standing very still and looking out at the sea. We cannot read her emotions because we don’t have access to her face. Thus, we have to imagine what she thinks and feels. 

In this respect, the image composition is interesting because a figure, seen from behind, looking out at something is often used as a device for a heightened submersion into the motif on the part of the spectator:

“…the presence of static figures, seen from behind […] permits the spectator a maximum of empathy, for he can easily take his place beside or within these faceless beings…” (Robert Rosenblum, Modern Painting and the Northern Romantic Tradition)

Furthermore, in the history of art, images of a figure looking out at the sea or a harbor with their back turned to the spectator has often been used to convey longing, fx for travel or adventure. Thus, it is not far-fetched to interpret this image of Sansa as her being submerged in a moment of longing for home, now that her hopes have been raised.

After this final shot of Sansa, looking out at the sea with longing, the screen  transitions to a scene on the open sea where Daenerys travels towards Astapor while her dragons fly free around the ship. In television and cinema, editing is an extremely important narrative device and it can carry a lot of meaning. Whilst Sansa’s and Daenerys’ narrative arcs are completely separate from each other, this transition from a woman longing for freedom to a woman who has embarked on a journey to take charge of her life and her ambitions forms a very poignant juxtaposition.

A WORRIED FRIEND

Sansa may have promised Baelish not to tell anyone about his plan to spirit her away from King’s Landing, but in the very next episode a scene between her and Shae in her chambers reveals that Sansa has confided in her maid. It isn’t stated directly but it can be deduced from the dialogue. What I find interesting is that Sansa promised Baelish to not tell as soul but here we have her discussing his offer with her maid and friend – and it just shows how much she trusts Shae.

We enter the scene mid-conversation, with Sansa telling Shae that Baelish said he didn’t want anything from her and that he’s only offering to help her because he loved her mother. Shae is, however, not quite convinced of the purity of Baelish’s intentions, courtesy of Ros’ warning.

Sansa, on the other hand, finds Shae’s insinuation rather ridiculous.

Sansa is right, he’s not in love with her. He wants to exploit her political status as Robb Stark’s heir. With the supposed deaths of Bran and Rickon Stark, Sansa has become the Robb’s heir in the eyes of Westeros - she is, politically speaking, the Key to the North if Robb dies and it is this political status that shapes her narrative arc in season 3.

I love Sansa’s expression here! Petyr Baelish is about the same age as her mother and to the rather innocent Sansa it is inconceivable that a man of that age could have a sexual interest in a 14 year-old girl. Shae knows better.

Shae: They never see it that way. He didn’t ask you to do something for him? Spy on someone or…

Sansa: No.

Sansa (smiling): Why? What would you do?

Shae: I will make him stop.

summary: If you care about victims of pedophilia you literally do have to understand that Tyrion, as an adult, is revictimized by the...
body: If you care about victims of pedophilia you literally do have to understand that Tyrion, as an adult, is revictimized by the person who abused him as a child, and is forcing him to abuse another child. That does not minimize Sansa’s abuse but it DOES affect how you talk about Tyrion in that situation. Tyrion is still a victim in that scene of his father’s pedophilic abuse of him. Understanding that does not excuse anything Sansa experiences. No, this isn’t “he was abused so that’s why he abuses others.” He is literally being revictimized in nearly the exact same way that he was as a child. That changes the entire situation. It doesn’t change things for Sansa but it does change who blame is assigned to, because Tywin is the one with the power in that situation and the one who is abusing both Sansa and Tyrion.

summary: I wanna be king in your story (I wanna know who you are)
title: I wanna be king in your story (I wanna know who you are)
body:
Part two of Everything I hold dear (resides in those eyes)

Pairing: Jon/Sansa, Aegon/Daenerys, Past!Jon/Daenerys

Rating: Teen

Summary: Jon travels south to see Daenerys marry Aegon, coming to terms with his own marriage and his place in the world.

AO3 Link: I wanna be king in your story (I wanna know who you are)

“Your Queen deserves her crown, I think,” Daenerys says at last, as if reading his thoughts, and takes his hand. He’s startled to see there are tears in her eyes.

“Thank you,” he says hoarsely and, on impulse, dips his head to press a kiss to her cheek, emotions threatening to overwhelm him. For all that had transpired between them, all the hurt and regret, he is grateful for her, for these final moments between them, like the gentle closing of a well-loved book before it is finally set aside.

tags: i love me some sansa quotes!
summary: mere! what are your favorite sansa quotes? I need help with my sansa character set! youre one of the sansa experts i know on...
question: mere! what are your favorite sansa quotes? I need help with my sansa character set! youre one of the sansa experts i know on this site! xD
answer:
omfgalskjdsjkgh YOU ARE TOO SWEET! yes okay LET’S DO IT!

I have SO MANY favorite Sansa quotes, I love her pov so much. Even though she can be an unreliable narrator, I love the way Sansa tells stories and uses language. She can be so dreamy and romantic and lyrical, but also so sharp and quick and witty at the drop of a hat…

  • I am Sansa Stark, Lord Eddard’s daughter and Lady Catelyn’s, the blood of Winterfell.
  • If I am ever a queen, I’ll make them love me.
  • I am stronger within the walls of Winterfell.
  • My skin has turned to porcelain, to ivory, to steel.
  • A kind of madness took over her then, and she heard herself say, “Maybe my brother will give me your head.”
  • She was a Stark of Winterfell, a noble lady, and someday she would be a queen. 
  • It was as if she had become a ghost, dead before her time. 
  • Sansa had no choice but to explain about heroes and monsters.
  • In Sansa’s dreams, her children looked just like the brothers she had lost. Sometimes there was even a girl who looked like Arya.
  • Charm him. Entrance him. Bewitch him. “If you insist.”
  • Drifting snowflakes brushed her face as light as lover’s kisses, and melted on her cheeks… She could feel the snow on her lashes, taste it on her lips. It was the taste of Winterfell. The taste of innocence. The taste of dreams.
  • Courtesy is a lady’s armor.
  • Once she had loved Prince Joffrey with all her heart, and admired and trusted her his mother, the queen. They had repaid that love and trust with her father’s head. Sansa would never make that mistake again.
  • Alayne was older, and bastard brave.
  • It sounds like a wolf, thought Sansa. A ghost wolf, big as mountains.
  • She was drunk on the magic of the night, giddy with glamour, swept away by beauties she had dreamt of all her life and never dared hope to know.
  • There are gods, she told herself, and there are true knights too. All the stories can’t be lies.
  • She’s not a dog, she’s a direwolf.

And of course, I must include my absolute, all time, FAVORITE ~Queen Sansa of the House Snark First of Her Name~ moment…

  • “As you wish, ser. And now if you will excuse me, Littlefinger’s bastard must find her lord father and let him know that you have come, so we can begin the tourney on the morrow.” And may your horse stumble, Harry the Heir, so you fall on your stupid head in your first tilt.

Thanks for the ask love! I know it was 15 minutes late without Starbucks, but hopefully it will be helpful someday lol ❤

  • Once she had loved Prince Joffrey with all her heart, and admired and trusted her his mother, the queen. They had repaid that love and trust with her father’s head. Sansa would never make that mistake again.
  • Alayne was older, and bastard brave.
  • It sounds like a wolf, thought Sansa. A ghost wolf, big as mountains.
  • She was drunk on the magic of the night, giddy with glamour, swept away by beauties she had dreamt of all her life and never dared hope to know.
  • There are gods, she told herself, and there are true knights too. All the stories can’t be lies.
  • She’s not a dog, she’s a direwolf.

And of course, I must include my absolute, all time, FAVORITE ~Queen Sansa of the House Snark First of Her Name~ moment…

  • “As you wish, ser. And now if you will excuse me, Littlefinger’s bastard must find her lord father and let him know that you have come, so we can begin the tourney on the morrow.” And may your horse stumble, Harry the Heir, so you fall on your stupid head in your first tilt.

Thanks for the ask love! I know it was 15 minutes late without Starbucks, but hopefully it will be helpful someday lol ❤

summary: They say the ice queen is kissed by fire. That her hair is like flames and she has a warm smile. But her eyes count a different...
body:
They say the ice queen is kissed by fire. That her hair is like flames and she has a warm smile. But her eyes count a different story. Her eyes are like ice, like wildness in her veins. She is the queen they go to war for. -author unknown

❄️✨❄️✨❄️✨❄️✨❄️✨❄️

I really love how Sansa has grown and developed over the course of the story. I’m almost finished with the third book, Storm of Swords.

I’m really partial to House Stark and House Targaryen myself. Honestly though, I would much rather be one of The Children of the Forest. Hehehe

Which House would you want to belong to?

❄️✨❄️✨❄️✨❄️✨❄️✨❄️✨
